36.text: We are here today to remember a War:

41.text: a war so large as to dwarf all the other wars before it.

46.text:
So encompassing, this war, that it brought
an entire globe into conflict.

53.text: A War fought with old alliances, with old grudges.

59.text:
On a Sunday morning in Sarajevo, at 10:45am,
two shots rang out, a single bullet of which,

71.text:
from a single gun, from a single individual:
one Gavrilo Princip, a Yugoslavian Nationalist,

80.text:
set in motion an extraordinary chain of events
that would ultimately bring the entire world

90.text:
His victim was none other than the heir to
the Austro-Hungarian throne, one Archduke

98.text:
Franz Ferdinand and his assassination on that
fateful Sunday morning precipitated a series

106.text:
of diplomatic manoeuvrings between these two
Empires, of Austria-Hungary and Serbia, which

114.text:
then led to an ultimatum from the late Archduke’s
Kingdom and ultimately a declaration of war

123.text: against the Serbians on the 28th July 1914.

131.text:
This then, invoked international alliances
which had been formed over the previous decades.

138.text:
Within weeks, nation after nation, empire
after empire, declared war upon one another

145.text: until the conflict had spread around the world.

150.text:
Knowing that the Serbian Empire were allies
of Russia, and also knowing that the Russians

155.text:
were mobilising along its own borders, Germany
declared war on the Russians in alliance with

166.text:
This led to the French, who were allies with
Russia. Germany declared war on France.

176.text:
Germany then, fearing a war on two fronts
decided the quicker victory could be gained

183.text:
against the French in the west. Germany had
a plan; The Schlieffen Plan, which was not

192.text:
to invade France directly but to instead invade
neutral Belgium, to then pierce down into

199.text:
France and head directly to Paris. Germany
invaded Belgium then, and it was this that

208.text: brought one more nation into the War.

213.text:
Ours. This Nation. This island. For years
Great Britain had been enjoying a time of

222.text:
isolation, of prosperity. This nation had
built the strongest naval fleet in the world.

230.text:
This nations Empire spread throughout the
world in common wealth.

235.text:
With Germany’s invasion of Belgium, it invoked
our treaty with Belgium. To protect her if

244.text:
ever she were at war. We declared our War
upon Germany on August 4th 1914. We believed

256.text:
we would win and be home by Christmas. Home
by Christmas was the call, Home by Christmas.”

316.text:
And as this nation gathered its sons to send
them as a British Expeditionary Force over

324.text:
…Then too did this isle begin to work in
supporting them. Volunteers; the number of

330.text:
which had rarely been seen before came forward
for the war effort. This very Borough can

335.text:
lay claim to being the first to step forward.
The very first. The Raynes Park district,

341.text:
raised a volunteer force within two days numbering
250 individuals. The Raynes Park Veteran Volunteer

349.text:
Merton and Morden followed suit in answering
the call. The Merton Volunteers - 300 men

355.text:
under Major F.W.Thorpe, all gearing themselves
towards aiding here from home and enlisting

361.text:
to do battle in Belgium. In total 1,300 Merton
and Morden men passed through these Companies,

368.text:
the majority of whom went to the frontline.
Lord Derby’s scheme itself raising well

375.text:
Lord Kitchener of Khartoum, Secretary of State
for War, began his great surging endeavour

380.text:
for an entire Volunteer army. The number of
men passing through the Merton Council offices

385.text:
near 700. In total his endeavour was answered
in the largest Volunteer Army the world had

395.text:
Training Corps - right off the bat. The famed
Volunteer Corps of Wimbledon, 120 men within

401.text:
days of the declaration. 600 within two months.
One of the most successful Corps in the kingdom,

408.text:
formed by sportsmen, 7 days a week, weekends
up on the common executing drills for those

415.text:
The Red Cross and St. John’s Ambulance,
those stalwarts of virtue. Hospitals, both

420.text:
established and newly formed through volunteers.
Nelson and Wimbledon, Ravensbury and Mitcham

426.text:
Hall and Morden Hall Military Hospital. Nurses,
those tireless servants working endlessly

432.text: in preparation to heal those returning.

435.text:
Societies; countless. Agricultural Committee,
Home Produce Society, Andrew Society, Choral

443.text:
Society, Ladies Committee, The Silver Thimbles,
Pig and Livestock Society, Queen Mary’s

448.text:
Needlework Guild, Boys Naval Brigade, and
the Church Army. All living to offer their

453.text:
support. All ready to work in a mass movement
to aid these soldiers.. let us not forget

459.text:
the
very land and the part of the allotments and

461.text:
their tenants, growing the necessary sustenance
for the effort ahead.”

476.text:
To Belgium, then. On the 9th August, 5 days
after Britain declared War, our British Expeditionary

485.text:
Force began embarking for France. The German
and French armies numbered well over a million

491.text:
men each; the BEF numbered 80,000 soldiers
divided into two corps of entirely professional

504.text:
Though we numbered far less than our counterparts
we were the best trained and most experienced

512.text:
of the European armies. Our training emphasised
rapid marksmanship.

519.text:
But let us not forget the inclusion of those
who before, during and after 1914 answered

529.text:
The Armies of India, Canada, Australia, New
Zealand, South Africa, and Portugal.

542.text: All answered the call to arms.

547.text:
On the 22nd of August, the British faced the
enemy for the very first time at the Battle

560.text:
The BEF reached Mons on the 21st August, where
first contact took place. Private John Parr

568.text:
becoming the first British Soldier to be killed
in the war. 6:30am on the 22nd August marked

575.text:
the first substantial action as the 4th Dragoon
Guards laid an ambush for a patrol of German

580.text:
Lancers outside the village of Casteau, to
the north-east of Mons. When the Germans spotted

586.text:
the trap and fell back, a troop of the dragoons,
led by Captain Hornby gave chase, followed

592.text:
by the rest of his squadron, all with drawn
sabres. The retreating Germans led the British

597.text:
to a larger force of lancers, whom they promptly
charged and Captain Hornby

601.text:
became the first British soldier to kill an
enemy in the Great War, fighting on horseback

606.text:
with sword against lance. After a further
pursuit of a few miles, the Germans turned

612.text:
and fired upon the British cavalry, at which
point the dragoons dismounted and opened fire.

618.text:
Drummer Edward Thomas is reputed to have fired
the first shot of the war for the British

626.text:
On the 22nd of August, The French Fifth Army
was already heavily

631.text:
engaged with the German 2nd and 3rd armies
at the Battle of Charleroi. We dug in along

641.text:
80,000 men. The Cavalry Division and two Corps;
each with two infantry divisions.

650.text:
Our weapons, along with our trusted Lee Enfield
rifles, were: 24 Vickers machine guns; 54

658.text:
18-pounder guns; 18 4.5-inch Howitzers and
a heavy artillery battery of 4 60-pounder

671.text:
The advancing Germans were commanded by Alexander
von Kluck and had the greatest offensive power

677.text: of all the German armies. Battle commenced…

683.text:
Dawn of the 23rd August saw German bombardment
on the British lines. At 9:00am the first

692.text:
German infantry assault began, the British
defending their lines exacted heavy casualties.

697.text:
So heavy was our rifle fire rate that the
Germans believed themselves to be facing a

703.text:
This initial German attack was repelled with
heavy losses.

708.text:
The second offensive came, this one proving
to be more successful.

715.text:
By the afternoon however it had become increasingly
clear that the British position was untenable.

721.text:
At 3:00pm the British 3rd Division received
the order to retreat. A similar retreat was

728.text:
ordered to the British 5th Division. Still
the Germans came in force. News then arrived

735.text:
that the French Fifth Army was retreating,
leaving the British forces dangerously exposed.

743.text:
Vastly outnumbered, The British fought to
inflict losses upon the enemy at a ratio of

749.text:
3:1. Losses on both sides numbered at 1,600
for the British and some 3-5000 for the Germans.

764.text:
The total losses numbered 516,000 for the
Allies of France, Britain and Belgium and

773.text:
more than 300,000 for the German Army. Belgium
had been lost. The War would go on.

875.text:
160,000 Belgian refugees arrived in Britain
in the wake of the German invasion. Some 800

883.text:
of which found themselves right here, in the
heart of Merton. The local people rose to

888.text:
the occasion and began public means to attend
to their new arrivals. Fund-raising events

893.text:
were held to aid them, one of which was attended
by members of the Belgium Royal Family no

898.text:
In October 1914, Her Royal Highness the Duchess
of Vendome, Princess of Belgium and His Royal

905.text:
Highness the Duke of Vendome, along with their
Royal Highnesses the Princess Marie Louise

909.text:
and the Princess Genevieve of Orleans, stepped
out onto the grass of Wimbledon Common for

914.text:
what would be known as The Salutation of the
Belgian Flag. An event to honour the resistance

919.text:
of the Belgians and raise funds for the 800
refugees billeted within the Borough of Merton.

925.text:
Song would be the order of the day. 1,500
children along with a full Salutation Choir

931.text:
under the direction of Dr. Coleman Young gave
choral ode and voice in honour of those who

936.text:
continued to fight for the defence of home
here and the recapture of homeland there.

940.text:
Here now, we shall have ourselves song in
remembrance of the voices that sung on that

946.text:
October 1914 day by the Colliers Wood Chorus
who will sing “A Salute To The Belgian Flag”

951.text:
By Alfred Percival Graves. An ode sung just
as it was then on that day in 1914.

1030.text:
To France, then. The Great Retreat culminated
in the allied forces finally coming together

1038.text:
to form a sound defensive line along the river
Marne on the very outskirts of Paris. A battle

1046.text:
the allies could ill afford to lose for to
do so would surely sound the death knell for

1052.text:
the capital city gaining Germany victory over
France and relieving Germany of a war on two

1064.text:
On approaching Paris, the German First and
Second Armies began their swerve to the south

1070.text:
east in an attempt to envelop the retreating
French Armies. Aware of this, the Allies made

1077.text:
plans to halt their continued withdrawal and
attack the Germans along the German front

1083.text:
with the French Sixth Army, numbering 150,000
men, and the British Expeditionary Force,

1095.text:
The German Army however detected this move
and so wheeled themselves around, opening

1104.text:
The Allies were quick to take hold of this
scant advantage in the German lines and duly

1108.text:
poured through with the French 5th Army and
dispatched troops of the BEF. The 8th September

1115.text:
saw the French launch another offensive, once
more attacking the German 2nd, widening the

1120.text:
gap further between the German 1st and 2nd
Armies.

1124.text:
By the 9th September the German First and
Second Armies feared they would be encircled

1128.text:
and destroyed and there for the first time
in the War came the call for a mass German

1133.text:
retreat, and that they did, some 64km north
to the Aisne River, where they dug in with

1139.text:
trenches that would ultimately last for four
long years in what would become the Western

1146.text:
Victory, then. Victory at the Miracle of the
Marne.

1154.text:
In repelling the German attempts at taking
Paris, the Allies had withstood a German victory

1160.text:
that would have seen them able to pour the
majority of their forces into the conflicts

1166.text:
against their Russian foe.
In defeat at the Marne they would now be drawn

1172.text: into a long costly conflict on two fronts.

1179.text:
It was unequivocally to prove one of the single
most important events of the entire Great

1184.text: War. Though the cost was also great.

1191.text:
Casualties at the Marne totalled half-a-million
men killed or wounded. The French alone 250,000

1205.text:
men, 80,000 of which had lost their lives.
British casualties: 13,000 men, 1,700 of which

1222.text:
also losing their lives. Germany: 250,000
men killed or wounded. The cost of victory.”

1252.text:
"Anthem for Doomed Youth"
by Wilfred Owen

1259.text:
What passing-bells for these who die as cattle?
— Only the monstrous anger of the guns.

1267.text:
Only the stuttering rifles' rapid rattle
Can patter out their hasty orisons.

1275.text:
No mockeries now for them; no prayers nor
bells;

1280.text:
Nor any voice of mourning save the choirs,—
The shrill, demented choirs of wailing shells;

1289.text: And bugles calling for them from sad shires.

1294.text:
What candles may be held to speed them all?
Not in the hands of boys, but in their eyes

1302.text:
Shall shine the holy glimmers of goodbyes.
The pallor of girls' brows shall be their

1309.text:
pall;
Their flowers the tenderness of patient minds,

1315.text: And each slow dusk a drawing-down of blinds.

1327.text:
Subsequent actions between the Allies and
their retreating German counterparts would

1333.text:
result in the Battle of the Aisne, a stalemate
costing the British 13,541 killed or wounded

1346.text: and the birth of Trench warfare.

1352.text:
Then into the “Race to the Sea”, an act
of both armies attempting to flank and out-flank

1357.text:
one another heading west and then sweeping
north manoeuvring and out-manoeuvring to envelop

1362.text:
the northern flanks of one another into the
Battle of La Bassée in October 1914, which

1368.text:
saw the German 6th Army taking Lille and the
German 4th Army attacking the British northern

1373.text:
flank. German reinforcements arrived after
the British claimed Givenchy-en-Gohelle, the

1379.text:
Germans reclaiming the initiative until the
arrival of the Indian 3rd Lahore Division

1384.text:
which repelled further German attacks. Other
Battles north along the line, Armentières

1389.text:
and Messines, proved equally unclear as to
the victor, both sides jostling for position

1394.text:
until early November when both forces began
to pour their numbers into the larger battle

1475.text:
The Ypres campaign marked the culmination
of 1914 and the first year of the Great War.

1484.text:
It witnessed the destruction of the British
Regular Army who, due to its small number,

1489.text:
could no longer bear the heavy losses. The
Old Contemptibles, so named and adopted as

1497.text:
a badge of honour, diminished into the ranks
of the British 1st and 2nd Armies along with

1504.text:
Lord Kitchener’s Volunteers. It would be
a battle of atrocious casualties.

1514.text:
Defeats at the First Battle of the Aisne and
the Miracle of the Marne convinced the German

1519.text: General Staff to insist on a swift resolution.

1524.text:
Ypres was strategically vital. It was the
last geographical object protecting the Allied

1533.text:
ports at Calais and Boulogne-sur-Mer. The
loss of these ports would have denied the

1539.text:
shortest logistical supply route to Allied
forces on the Western Front and would have

1550.text:
For the German Army, Ypres was equally vital.
The collapse of its front would allow the

1555.text:
Allied armies access to the relatively traversable
terrain of Flanders. Beyond Ypres, the Germans

1562.text:
had no significant defensive barrier to protect
the huge rail network axis, vital to German

1567.text:
mobility in Belgium and the entire Northern
flank of their front.

1571.text:
Here, then, in Flanders, after surging north,
flanking and counter-flanking one another,

1577.text: the war in the west would be decided.

1580.text:
In October 1914, the Germans, as a prelude
to General Falkenhayn’s Flanders Offensive,

1589.text:
captured Antwerp and forced its Belgian defenders
back to Nieuport, near Ypres.

1597.text:
Under the command of Field Marshall Sir John
French, the British

1601.text:
Expeditionary Force retreated to Ypres after
Antwerp fell.

1607.text:
The BEF held their line in the centre while
the French Army manned the flanks to the south

1613.text:
of the city. At the outset of the battle,
the BEF and French Army both retained the

1620.text:
hope of launching an offensive of their own.
They believed a coordinated attack would enable

1627.text:
the Allies to recapture the industrial city
of Lille, followed swiftly by Brussels.

1636.text: The Germans however, had other ideas.

1641.text:
On the 20th October, Falkenhayn's German Flanders
Offensive began when he ordered an advance

1647.text:
to break through the Allied line and capture
the ports of Dunkirk, Calais, and Boulogne.

1653.text:
He struck the Belgian defences on the Yser
River between Dixmude and Nieuport. The already

1658.text:
weakened Belgian Army fought valiantly, but
the German actions forced Belgium's King Albert

1664.text: to open the sluices that held back the sea.

1667.text:
A week later, the Belgians flooded the land
between their positions and the Germans along

1672.text:
the twenty-mile strip between Dixmude and
Nieuport, creating a two-mile wide water barrier,

1681.text: To the city of Ypres, then.

1685.text:
Falkenhayn had at his disposal the newly assembled
Fourth German

1689.text:
Army made up of units from the siege of Antwerp
and eight new

1693.text:
divisions manned by underage recruits. Now
the Germans could claim an even greater numerical

1704.text:
The BEF, however, could count on Indian troops
already en route as reinforcements. Though

1711.text:
low in number these Indian units would soon
prove to be the most outstanding fighters.

1719.text:
On the 31st October, German cavalry drove
a smaller British cavalry unit from its position

1725.text:
on the Messines Ridge. The German forces engaged
General Douglas Haig’s First Corps further

1732.text:
to the north, but a ferocious British counterattack
repelled the Germans.

1740.text:
On the 11th November, two premier German divisions
attempted to break the British lines just

1745.text:
north of the Menin Road in the Nuns' Woods
only four miles from Ypres. Initially successful

1751.text:
in creating a breakthrough, the Germans were
slow to exploit their gains. German indecisiveness

1756.text:
enabled the British to assemble a collection
of soldiers: Engineers, Servants, Orderlies,

1762.text:
Clerks and Cooks who stemmed the enemy advance
and drove the German force back to their own

1769.text:
On the 22nd November, Winter finally arrived;
settling upon the fields of battle, forcing

1782.text:
The battles fought had been unrelenting. To
say one had been at “First Ypres” was

1790.text:
enough to convey the horrors endured. No further
words were necessary.

1798.text: The deciding battle of 1914 had ended.

1805.text:
The gunfire and bloodshed of 1914 had slowed
to a cease within winter’s grip. The realisation

1812.text:
on both fronts that a swift war and victory
for either, no longer the reality.

1816.text:
The total number of losses during the 1914
War in the west may never truly be known.

1824.text:
Accounts total the number of dead to at least
half a million killed or died from wounds,

1829.text: in five months. Half a million sons.

1833.text:
In this Borough, in this Borough of Merton
alone we would know the loss of 9,000 over

1839.text: the course of the entire war.

1842.text:
The War would drag on, of course, for a further
three years, and the death toll would rise

1851.text:
as soldier after soldier and civilian after
civilian gave their lives to a cause. Causes

1860.text:
triggered by a single bullet, from a single
gun, from a single man.

1871.text:
So as 1914 ended so must we. We conclude now
with words from the Wimbledon born poet, Robert

1895.text:
In the fields between La Bassée and Bethune;
Primroses and the first warm day of Spring,

1901.text:
Red poppy floods of June,
August, and yellowing Autumn, so

1906.text:
To Winter nights knee-deep in mud or snow,
And you’ve been everything.

1911.text:
Dear, you’ve been everything that I most
lack

1920.text:
Music, the quiet of an English wood,
Beautiful comrade-looks,

1925.text:
The narrow, bouldered mountain-track,
The broad, full-bosomed ocean, green and black,

1934.text: And Peace, and all that’s good.

1959.text:
Ladies and gentleman, boys and girls, as we
close Merton’s Commemorative Event 2014,

1969.text:
where we have been remembering the events
of 1914 and how our people of Merton were

1976.text:
affected at that time I would ask you all
to take a moment just to reflect on all that

1982.text:
we have heard today and remember all those
people who did so much to ensure that we are

1988.text: able to be here today to commemorate them.

1994.text:
Thank you today to our narrators Christopher
Fairbank and Claire Walshe – I must say

2001.text:
Mr Fairbank I could be listening to you
all day, thank you –

2013.text:
brass band and choir for making this a memorable
moment in our borough’s history.

2019.text:
Thank you also to Asheq Akhtar from the Leisure
and Culture Team for the production of this

2025.text:
event and to all the staff, volunteers, artists
and production team for all the work that

2031.text:
has gone in to making this event happen, it’s
been wonderful. Thank you to the Colliers

2035.text:
Wood choir as well, they’re a great bunch
of people.

2040.text:
Thank you for all of you that have attended
today. I encourage you now to remain and enjoy

2046.text:
the music from the Regent Brass Band who will
continue to play for your entertainment for

2052.text:
a while longer. Let the music begin. And thank
you all very much for coming.
